sections.Overview: Jaborandi is a plant found in Brazil. It has a traditional history of use in medicine, but is no longer used due to safety concerns. Jaborandi has been used in the production of pilocarpine (18). Avoid confusing jaborandi with Pilocarpus jaborandi (Pernambuco jaborandi) (19) and Pilocarpus pennatifolius (Paraguay jaborandi).
sections.Safety:
UNSAFE when the leaf is used orally or topically due to its pilocarpine constituent. The lethal dose of jaborandi is estimated to be 5-10 grams of leaf (18).
PREGNANCY: UNSAFE when used orally or topically because it has teratogenic and uterine stimulant effects and contains pilocarpine(19).
LACTATION: UNSAFE when used orally or topically because it contains pilocarpine (18).
sections.Adverse Effects:
EXPAND ALL
|
COLLAPSE ALL
General
Orally, jaborandi can cause toxicity. Symptoms of jaborandi poisoning include bradycardia, bronchospasm, colic, cardiac collapse and possible arrest, convulsions, hypotension, dyspnea, nausea, severe salivation, strong secretion of sweat, and vomiting. The lethal oral dose of jaborandi leaf is approximately 5-10 grams (18).
Cardiovascular
Orally, cardiovascular symptoms of jaborandi poisoning include bradycardia, cardiac collapse and possible arrest, and hypotension (18).
less
Gastrointestinal
Orally, gastrointestinal symptoms of jaborandi poisoning include colic, nausea, and vomiting (18).
less
Neurologic/CNS
Orally, neurologic symptoms of jaborandi poisoning include convulsions, severe salivation, and strong secretion of sweat (18).
less
Pulmonary/Respiratory
Orally, pulmonary symptoms of jaborandi poisoning include bronchospasm and dyspnea (18).
less

No typical dosage.

There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of jaborandi.
sections.Interactions with Drugs: None known.
sections.Interactions with Supplements: None known.
sections.Interactions with Lab Tests:
INTRAOCULAR PRESSURE
Jaborandi might reduce intraocular pressure due to its pilocarpine content (15, 18).
less
sections.Overdose: The lethal oral dose of the pilocarpine constituent in jaborandi is approximately 60 mg, corresponding to approximately 5-10 grams of jaborandi leaf (18).
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable part of jaborandi is the leaf. Jaborandi contains the parasympathetic system stimulants pilocarpine and epiisopilosine. Other alkaloids include pilosine, isopilosine, epiisopiloturine, and macaubine (18, 102775).
Cholinergic effects
Pilocarpine, a constituent of jaborandi, has cholinergic activity and stimulates saliva secretion, sweat, and smooth muscle contraction in the gastrointestinal tract (18). It also causes ocular miosis (15).

sections.Overview: The jackfruit tree is native to southwestern India but is now widely cultivated in other countries, including Sri Lanka, Malaysia, Burma, Indonesia, East Africa, Jamaica, and Brazil (90490). The wood of the tree is used for furniture and musical instruments, and the fruit and seeds are consumed as food (90491). Jackfruit leaves, roots, bark, and latex have been used for medicinal purposes in Ayurveda (98374, 98375, 98396).
sections.Safety:
There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of jackfruit.
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid amounts in excess of those found in foods.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
There is currently a limited amount of information on the adverse effects of jackfruit.
Serious Adverse Effects (Rare)
Orally: Serious allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, in sensitive individuals.
Immunologic
Orally, the fruit of jackfruit might cause serious allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, in sensitive individuals (98378, 112050). In one case report, a 34-year-old female developed anaphylaxis with symptoms of cough, dyspnea, facial swelling, and urticaria after eating 10 pieces of dried jackfruit. There is speculation that latex allergy might result in a cross-reactivity to jackfruit (98378). In another case report, a 21-year-old male developed anaphylaxis with symptoms of ocular pruritis, periorbital swelling, dyspnea, and urticaria 15 minutes after eating a small piece of dried jackfruit. The patient had a history of latex allergy and tested positive for jackfruit and latex allergies upon skin prick testing (112050).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Diabetes. Small clinical studies suggest that oral jackfruit flour or leaf extract might improve glycemic control in patients with diabetes.
A small clinical study in patients with type 2 diabetes shows that replacing rice or wheat flour in the diet with green jackfruit flour 30 grams daily for 12 weeks reduces glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) by 0.27%, fasting blood glucose by around 13 mg/dL, and postprandial blood glucose by around 28 mg/dL when compared with placebo flour (112155). Another small clinical study in patients with type 2 diabetes shows that taking jackfruit leaf extract 10 mL/kg one hour prior to an oral glucose tolerance test attenuates the percentage increase in blood glucose at 1.5 and 2 hours after eating when compared with a control (26885). The jackfruit extract was prepared by boiling 200 grams of jackfruit leaves in one liter of water and then reducing the volume of the extract to 200 mL.
less
Wound healing. Although there has been interest in using topical jackfruit for wound healing, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of jackfruit for this purpose.
More evidence is needed to rate jackfruit for these uses.
sections.Dosing & Administration:
Adult
Oral:
Research is limited; typical dosing is unavailable.
Standardization & Formulation
There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of jackfruit.

Interaction Rating
MODERATE Be cautious with this combination.
Severity
MODERATE
Occurrence
POSSIBLE
Level of Evidence
D (In vitro or animal study)
Theoretically, jackfruit latex might increase the risk of bleeding when taken with anticoagulant or antiplatelet drugs.
Jackfruit latex, which is the sap from jackfruit bark, contains chemicals that might increase the risk of bleeding. In vitro research shows that jackfruit latex contains a glycoprotein constituent that prolongs the activated partial thrombin time (aPTT) and reduces the activity of blood coagulation factors XIa and alpha-XIIa (98376). Jackfruit latex also contains a protease constituent that has been shown to have fibrinolytic activity in vitro (98377). Other parts of jackfruit, including the fruit and leaves, have not been shown to contain chemicals with fibrinolytic and anticoagulant activity.

Theoretically, jackfruit latex might have anticoagulant effects.
Taking jackfruit latex, which is the sap from jackfruit bark, with other products that increase the risk of bleeding might have additive effects (98376, 98377). This potential interaction applies only to jackfruit latex and not other jackfruit plant parts. See products with anticoagulant activity here. See products with antiplatelet activity here.

Theoretically, jackfruit might have hypoglycemic effects.
Taking jackfruit with other products with hypoglycemic potential might increase the risk of hypoglycemia. Small clinical studies show that jackfruit flour and leaf extract can reduce fasting and postprandial blood glucose (26885, 112155). See other products with hypoglycemic potential here.

Theoretically, jackfruit seeds might have sedative effects.
Taking jackfruit seeds with other products with sedative properties might cause additive sedation. Animal research shows that jackfruit seeds can cause sedation (26886). See other products with sedative properties here.

CROSS-ALLERGENICITY
Jackfruit might cause an allergic reaction in individuals sensitive to birch pollen or latex (26887, 98378, 112050). Until more is known, avoid or use with caution in individuals with allergies to birch pollen or latex.
less
PERIOPERATIVE
Jackfruit seeds might have sedative effects (26886), and jackfruit latex might have anticoagulant effects. Theoretically, jackfruit seeds might cause additive CNS depression and jackfruit latex might cause excessive bleeding if used perioperatively. Tell patients to discontinue jackfruit seeds and latex at least 2 weeks before elective surgical procedure.
less
sections.Overdose: There is insufficient reliable information available about the presentation or treatment of overdose with jackfruit.
sections.Pharmacokinetics: There is insufficient reliable information available about the pharmacokinetics of jackfruit.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable parts are the fruit, seeds, leaves, latex, bark, and roots of jackfruit. The seeds and fruit have been used for food, while the leaves and roots have been used orally for medicinal purposes. Jackfruit latex and bark are usually used topically for medicinal purposes (98374, 98375, 98396). Jackfruit seeds have been shown to contain about 5% protein and 11% dietary fiber (98375). Jacalin, a lectin isolated from jackfruit seeds, is considered the major protein of the seeds (26880, 26882, 26888, 26889, 26890, 26891). Jackfruit seeds have also been shown to contain potassium, calcium, manganese and magnesium (26892, 98376). The flesh of jackfruit is a source of carbohydrates, vitamin A, and also fiber and protein (98375).
Anti-inflammatory effects
There is interest in using jackfruit for inflammatory disorders. Preliminary research shows that certain phenolic constituents in jackfruit such norartocarpetin, oxyresveratrol, and especially artocarpesin have in vitro anti-inflammatory effects, such as reducing protein expression of cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) (98374).
Antibacterial activity
Traditionally, jackfruit bark is made into poultices to be used topically, while jackfruit leaves are heated and placed on wounds to prevent infection and promote healing. In vitro evidence suggests that extracts of jackfruit bark, wood, leaves, fruit, and seeds have antibacterial effects (26877, 98396).
Antidiabetic effects
In traditional Ayurvedic medicine, the hot water extract of mature jackfruit leaves is used to reduce blood sugar in diabetes (98375). Preliminary clinical research shows that taking jackfruit leaf extract orally can attenuate postprandial percentage increases in blood glucose in patients with diabetes (26885). Additional preliminary clinical research shows that jackfruit meal has a low glycemic index. It contains compounds such as lectin which can bind glucose slowing its absorption or digestion resulting in a lower glycemic response (98375).
Antifungal activity
In vitro research shows that jackin, a chitin-binding lectin from jackfruit, inhibits the growth of Fusarium moniliforme and Saccharomyces cerevisiae (26382). However, other in vitro research suggests that extracts of jackfruit bark, wood, leaves, fruit, and seeds do not have antifungal activity (26877).
Antiviral activity
In vitro research shows that a jackfruit lectin has antiviral activity against herpes simplex virus type 2, varicella-zoster virus, and cytomegalovirus (26879).
Gastrointestinal effects
Animal research suggests that polysaccharides extracted from jackfruit pulp have protective effects on intestinal barrier function, possibly by inhibiting inflammatory genes, increasing the expression of occludin, a protein involved in the regulation of the intestinal barrier, and activating signaling pathways associated with short-chain fatty acid production (112154).
Hematological effects
There is interest in using jackfruit latex to reduce the formation of clots in disorders such as strokes, pulmonary embolus, and deep vein thrombosis. In vitro studies suggest that jackfruit milky latex contains a glycoprotein constituent that might prolong the activated partial thrombin time (aPTT) by inhibiting serine protease and reducing the activity of blood coagulation factors XIa and alpha-XIIa (98376). Jackfruit latex also contains a protease constituent that has been shown to have fibrinolytic activity in vitro (98377). Other in vitro research suggests that jackin, a lectin isolated from jackfruit seeds, induces hemagglutination in human and rabbit erythrocytes (26382).
Immunological activity
In vitro research suggests that various lectins extracted from jackfruit, particularly the seeds, exhibit immunostimulative effects, mainly with respect to lymphoblastic transformation and mitogenic stimulation, often by stimulating CD4+ T lymphocytes and natural killer cells (26879, 26880, 26881, 26882, 26883, 26884).

sections.Overview: Jalap is a plant. It has traditionally been used in medicine (12, 271).
sections.Safety:
UNSAFE when used orally. Jalap has potent purgative effects (12).
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: UNSAFE when used orally. Jalap can be a menstrual stimulant (19); avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
Orally, jalap has potent purgative effects (12).
Gastrointestinal
Orally, jalap has potent purgative effects (12).

Interaction Rating
MODERATE Be cautious with this combination.
Severity
HIGH
Occurrence

D (Theoretical based on pharmacology)
Jalap has diuretic effects (19). Overuse of jalap might compound diuretic-induced potassium loss (19). There is some concern that people taking jalap along with potassium depleting diuretics might have an increased risk for hypokalemia.
Some diuretics that can deplete potassium include chlorothiazide (Diuril), chlorthalidone (Thalitone), furosemide (Lasix), hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ, Hydrodiuril, Microzide), and others.

MODERATE Be cautious with this combination.

Jalap has stimulant laxative effects (19). In some people jalap can cause diarrhea. Diarrhea can increase the effects of warfarin, increase international normalized ratio (INR), and increase the risk of bleeding. Advise patients who take warfarin not to take excessive amounts of jalap.
sections.Interactions with Supplements:
EXPAND ALL
|
COLLAPSE ALL
CARDIAC GLYCOSIDE-CONTAINING HERBS
Jalap has stimulant laxative activity (19). Overuse of jalap may increase the risk of cardiac glycoside toxicity. Cardiac glycoside-containing herbs include black hellebore, Canadian hemp roots, digitalis leaf, hedge mustard, figwort, lily of the valley roots, motherwort, oleander leaf, pheasant's eye plant, pleurisy root, squill bulb leaf scales, and strophanthus seeds (19). Jalap may increase risk of cardioglycoside toxicity due to increase risk of potassium loss.
HORSETAIL
Jalap has diuretic effects (19). Theoretically, concomitant use with horsetail increases the risk of potassium depletion.
LICORICE
Jalap has diuretic effects (19). Theoretically, concomitant use with licorice increases the risk of potassium depletion.
STIMULANT LAXATIVE HERBS
Jalap has stimulant laxative activity (19). Theoretically, concomitant use with other stimulant laxative herbs may increase the risk of potassium depletion. Stimulant laxative herbs include aloe, alder buckthorn, black root, blue flag, butternut bark, colocynth, European buckthorn, fo ti, gamboge, gossypol, greater bindweed, jalap, manna, Mexican scammony root, rhubarb, senna, and yellow dock.
sections.Interactions with Conditions:
GASTROINTESTINAL (GI) CONDITIONS
Jalap is a stimulant laxative and may have GI irritant effects (19). Contraindicated in individuals with intestinal obstruction, appendicitis, and infectious or inflammatory gastrointestinal conditions (19).
less
sections.Overdose: There is insufficient reliable information available about the toxicology of jalap.
sections.Pharmacokinetics: There is insufficient reliable information available about the pharmacokinetics of jalap.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable part of jalap is the root. The roots of the jalap plant contain gluco-resins that act as a cathartic. They increase water elimination and cause peristalsis (271).

sections.Overview: Jamaican dogwood is a tree. The root bark is used in medicine. However, it has no documented effectiveness and is considered to be toxic (4, 11, 18).
sections.Warnings: Jamaican dogwood is considered to be toxic (4, 11, 18).
sections.Safety:
LIKELY UNSAFE when the root bark is used orally for self-medication because it is considered toxic (4). The elderly are particularly sensitive to the potent neuro-muscular depressant effects of Jamaican dogwood root bark (19).
CHILDREN: LIKELY UNSAFE when used orally; avoid using. Children are particularly sensitive to the potent, neuro-muscular depressant effects of Jamaican dogwood (19).
PREGNANCY: LIKELY UNSAFE when used orally; avoid using due to possible uterine depressant effects (4).
LACTATION: LIKELY UNSAFE when used orally (4); avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
Orally, Jamaican dogwood is an irritant and toxic to humans (4).
Serious Adverse Effects (Rare)
Orally: Numbness, salivation, sweating, tremors.
Neurologic/CNS
Orally, Jamaican dogwood root bark can cause neuro-muscular depressant effects, numbness, tremors, salivation, sedation, and sweating (4, 19).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Anxiety. Although there has been interest in using oral Jamaican dogwood for anxiety, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Jamaican dogwood for this condition.
Dysmenorrhea. Although there has been interest in using oral Jamaican dogwood for dysmenorrhea, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Jamaican dogwood for this condition.
Insomnia. Although there has been interest in using oral Jamaican dogwood for insomnia, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Jamaican dogwood for this condition.
Migraine headache. Although there has been interest in using oral Jamaican dogwood for migraine headache, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Jamaican dogwood for this condition.
Neuropathic pain. Although there has been interest in using oral Jamaican dogwood for neuropathic pain, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Jamaican dogwood for this condition.
More evidence is needed to rate Jamaican dogwood for these uses.

sections.Overdose:
Presentation
Overdose with Jamaican dogwood may present with numbness, tremors, salivation, and sweating (4, 19).
Treatment
There is insufficient reliable information available about the treatment of overdose with Jamaican dogwood.
sections.Pharmacokinetics: There is insufficient reliable information available about the pharmacokinetics of Jamaican dogwood.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable part of Jamaican dogwood is the root bark. Constituents include rotenone, ichtynone, and isoflavones (4, 11, 56909).
Anti-cancer effects
The Jamaican dogwood constituent rotenone has shown some anticancer activity towards lymphocytic leukemia and human epidermoid carcinoma of the nasopharynx; yet, paradoxically, rotenone is also documented to be carcinogenic (4).
Sedative effects
Animal studies have shown that an extract of Jamaican dogwood has sedative effects (4, 11).
Spasmolytic effects
Animal studies have shown that an extract of Jamaican dogwood has antispasmodic action on smooth muscles (4, 11). The antispasmodic effects of Jamaican dogwood extract have been at least as strong as the effects of papaverine in vitro (4). The spasmolytic effects of Jamaican dogwood may be attributable to the isoflavone constituents (56909).

sections.Overview: Jambolan is an evergreen tree growing up to 30 meters in height. It is found in India, Bangladesh, Malaysia, South America, Asia, China, and Australia (18, 13595, 99063, 99064). Jambolan is used in folk medicine for treating diabetes, and has long been used in Ayurvedic medicine (99063).
sections.Safety:
POSSIBLY SAFE when used orally and appropriately, short-term. Jambolan tea prepared from 2 grams of jambolan leaves per liter of water has been consumed in place of water with apparent safety in clinical research (13092).
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
No adverse effects have been reported; however, a thorough evaluation of safety outcomes has not been conducted.
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Diabetes. Clinical research shows that drinking jambolan tea 2 grams, prepared with jambolan leaves in one liter of water, does not improve fasting blood glucose in patients with type 2 diabetes when compared with placebo (13092).
Clinical research in patients with prediabetes and those with newly-diagnosed type 2 diabetes shows that taking a combination product (GlycaCare-II, Sami-Sabinsa Group Ltd.) providing jambolan dried fruit extract 20 mg orally twice daily for 120 days is associated with similar decreases in glycated hemoglobin levels, and fasting and postprandial glucose levels, to metformin orally 500 mg twice daily. The combination product also contains cassia cinnamon bark extract, bitter melon fruit extract, heartwood extract, gymnema leaf extract, and Salacia bark extract (112762). It is not clear whether the changes are due to jambolan, other ingredients, or the combination. The validity of the results is also reduced by compliance issues and the lack of a per-protocol analysis.
less
Venous leg ulcers. Clinical research in patients with venous leg ulcers shows that applying hydrocolloid gel dressings containing an extract of jambolan flowers, seeds, and bark for about 6 months does not improve the overall healing rate or speed of healing when compared with the hydrocolloid dressing alone (112763).
More evidence is needed to rate jambolan for these uses.
sections.Dosing & Administration:

There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of jambolan.

Theoretically, jambolan might have additive effects when used with antidiabetes drugs. This might increase the risk of hypoglycemia in some patients. Monitor blood glucose levels closely.

Interaction Rating
MINOR Be watchful with this combination.
Severity
MILD
Occurrence
POSSIBLE
Level of Evidence
D (In vitro or animal study)
Animal research shows that jambolan seed extract reduces the sitagliptin maximum plasma concentration and area under the curve by 39% and 22%, respectively. However, blood glucose levels were actually reduced to a greater extent in mice taking jambolan and sitagliptin in combination when compared with either product taken alone (104282). Theoretically, jambolan seed extract might alter the clearance of sitagliptin, although this may not alter the clinical effects of sitagliptin.
sections.Interactions with Supplements:
HERBS AND SUPPLEMENTS WITH HYPOGLYCEMIC POTENTIAL
Jambolan seed and bark extracts might lower blood glucose levels (13599, 13600, 13601). Theoretically, jambolan might have additive effects when used with other herbs and supplements that also lower glucose levels. This might increase the risk of hypoglycemia in some patients. Some herbs and supplements with hypoglycemic effects include alpha-lipoic acid, bitter melon, carqueja, chromium, devil's claw, fenugreek, garlic, guar gum, horse chestnut, Panax ginseng, psyllium, Siberian ginseng, and others.
sections.Interactions with Conditions:
PERIOPERATIVE
Jambolan seed and bark extracts might affect blood glucose levels (13599, 13600, 13601, 104282). Theoretically, jambolan might interfere with blood glucose control during and after surgical procedures. Tell patients to discontinue jambolan at least 2 weeks before elective surgical procedures.
less
sections.Overdose: There is insufficient reliable information available about the presentation or treatment of overdose with jambolan.
sections.Pharmacokinetics: There is insufficient reliable information available about the pharmacokinetics of jambolan.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable parts of jambolan are the seeds, leaves, fruit, roots, stems, and bark. Jambolan seeds contain flavonoids, glycosides, triterpenoids, saponins, and tannin constituents, including corilagin, ellagic acid, gallic acid, and galloyl glucose (18, 13595). The seeds also contain epicatechin, isoquercetin, caffeic acid, ferulic acid, guaiacol, resorcinol dimethyl ether, lignaglucoside, veratrole, beta-sitosterol, and palmitic acid (99063). The seed oil contains oleic, myristic, palmitic, linoleic, sterculiac, malvalic, and vernolic acids (18). Jambolan fruit contains ellagic acid, ellagitannins, polyphenolics, several anthocyanins (malvidin, petunidin, delphinidin, cyanidin, and peonidin). and several triterpenoids (maslinic, ursolic, corosolic, and oleanolic acids) (99065, 99066). The fruit is also rich in vitamins and minerals (99066). Jambolan bark contains tannins, sterols such as beta-sitosterol, triterpenes (betulinic acid, friedelin, eugenin), and flavonoids (myricetin, kaempferol, quercetin, and astragalin) (18).
Anti-inflammatory effects
Preliminary research suggests jambolan bark extract might have anti-inflammatory activity, possibly by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis. However, it doesn't seem to have ulcerogenic effects (13603). Some research suggests that tannins extracted from jambolan might have gastroprotective and anti-ulcerogenic effects (13606).
Anti-obesity effects
Research in rats fed a high-carbohydrate, high-fat diet shows that giving jambolan seed powder reduces weight gain, adipose tissue weights, plasma lipid levels, and liver function changes compared with control rats receiving the diet alone. Liver function tests are improved, and inflammatory cell infiltration, fatty droplet deposition, and fibrosis in the liver are prevented (99063).
Anti-oxidant effects
Preliminary research indicates that jambolan seed and fruit pulp extracts have antioxidant effects (13604, 13605, 99065). In obese rats, giving jambolan seed powder for 56 days is associated with increases in antioxidant enzyme activity, including superoxide dismutase, catalase, and glutathione (99063). Jambolan seed extracts also appear to reduce tissue damage in the brain in experimental models of diabetes, possibly through an antioxidant effect (13607). Jambolan seed extracts also seem to protect against the effects of exposure to gamma radiation (13608).
Anticancer effects
Jambolan fruit pulp and seed extracts have shown antiproliferative activity against human lung cancer cells in vitro (99065).
Antidiabetic effects
Some animal research indicates that jambolan leaves and fruit do not have antidiabetic activity (13092, 13588, 13596, 13597, 13598), while extracts of the seeds and bark do (13599, 13600, 13601, 99063). However, diabetic mice that received a triterpenoid-enriched extract of jambolan fruit for 10 days had reductions in hyperglycemia, glucose intolerance, and hepatic gluconeogenesis. Jambolan seemed to work by protecting pancreatic islet morphology, preserving pancreatic beta-cell function and improving insulin secretion (99066). Other preliminary research in animals suggests that jambolan seed might have a lipid-lowering effect in diabetes-related hyperlipidemia (13602).
Antimicrobial effects
Preliminary research suggests jambolan seed extracts might have antibacterial and antifungal activity (13609). Other preliminary research suggests essential oil in jambolan leaves might also have antibacterial effects (13610). In vitro, extracts of jambolan bark and leaves have shown virucidal activity against the H5N1 avian influenza virus (99064).
Effects on hepatic enzymes
Inhibition of hepatic cytochrome P450 (CYP) 2C9 enzymes by a jambolan seed extract has been reported in vitro. There was also dose-dependent inhibition of diclofenac metabolism which occurs via CYP2C9 (99067). The in vitro tests also suggested that jambolan seed extract causes very weak inhibition of CYP3A4 and CYP2D6, which is unlikely to be clinically significant (99067).

sections.Overview: Japanese apricot is a deciduous tree that produces a small yellow fruit. The fruit and juice have been used as food and traditional medicine for at least 1000 years (100020, 100023, 100026, 100029, 114030).
sections.Safety:
LIKELY SAFE when the processed fruit is used orally in food amounts. Advise patients to only consume Japanese apricot fruit products that have been processed through pickling or other means to eliminate toxic constituents. The raw fruit is considered toxic because it contains the cyanogenic glycosides prunasin and amygdalin (13198).
POSSIBLY SAFE when Japanese apricot dried fruit extract is used orally and appropriately, short-term. A specific Japanese apricot dried fruit extract has been used safely in doses of up to 300 mg daily for up to 12 weeks (100027).
POSSIBLY UNSAFE when the raw fruit is used orally in food amounts. The raw fruit is considered toxic because it contains the cyanogenic glycosides prunasin and amygdalin (13198). Advise patients to only consume Japanese apricot fruit products that have been processed through pickling or other means to eliminate these toxic constituents.

There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of other forms of Japanese apricot.
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
EXPAND ALL
|
COLLAPSE ALL
General
Orally, Japanese apricot dried fruit extract seems to be well tolerated. Side effects reported in clinical research include gastric intolerance (100027). Diluted Japanese apricot juice concentrate may cause constipation (100029). Allergies to Japanese apricot are rare (100028). The raw fruit of Japanese apricot is thought to be toxic due to the cyanogenic glycosides prunasin and amygdalin (13198).
Gastrointestinal
Orally, Japanese apricot dried fruit extract 300 mg daily has been reported to cause gastric intolerance in one patient in one clinical study (100027). In other clinical research, dilute Japanese apricot juice concentrate has been reported to cause constipation in one patient (100029).
less
Immunologic
Orally, food-dependent, exercise-induced anaphylaxis related to Japanese apricot has been reported, but this is rare. In one case, symptoms including loss of consciousness occurred in a 12-year-old girl who had eaten Japanese apricot at breakfast and went jogging 90 minutes later (100028).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Population research suggests that individuals who consume dried or pickled Japanese apricot at least once daily are 37% less likely to have GERD and approximately 28% less likely to have symptoms of gastrointestinal dysmotility when compared to those who consume Japanese apricot less than once daily. However, consumption of Japanese apricot does not seem to be associated with a reduced risk of reflux symptoms. Also, benefits do not occur in elderly individuals or in those with Helicobacter pylori infection (100020).
Helicobacter pylori. A small preliminary clinical trial shows that taking a 1% Japanese apricot solution, known as Bainiku-ekisu solution, 130 mL twice daily for 12 weeks does not reduce Helicobacter pylori infection compared with baseline (100029). Also, population research shows that consuming dried or pickled Japanese apricot at least three times daily is not associated with a reduced rate of H. pylori infection when compared to consuming Japanese apricot less often. However, when stratified by age, there is some evidence that higher intake of dried or pickled Japanese apricot may reduce the risk of H. pylori infection in younger but not elderly patients (100026). Further clinical research is needed in a larger population.
Hepatitis C. Preliminary clinical research in patients with hepatitis C shows that taking Japanese apricot extract (Misatol ME, AdaBio Co. Ltd.) 6.5 grams twice daily for 12 weeks reduces levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) by 31% and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) by 29% when compared with baseline (100023). It is unclear if taking if this product affects viral load or the progression of chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.
Hypertension. Preliminary clinical research in patients with mild to moderate hypertension shows that taking Japanese apricot polyphenols 800 mg daily for 12 weeks does not reduce blood pressure when compared to placebo (100021). A larger study is needed in order to confirm these findings.
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Preliminary clinical research in patients with NAFLD shows that taking Japanese apricot extract (Misatol ME, AdaBio Co. Ltd.) 6.5 grams twice daily for 12 weeks reduces levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) by 31% each when compared with baseline (100023). It is unclear if taking if this product reduces the risk of NAFLD complications.
More evidence is needed to rate Japanese apricot for these uses.
sections.Dosing & Administration:
Adult
Oral:
Hepatitis C: Japanese apricot extract (Misatol ME, AdaBio Co. Ltd.) 6.5 grams twice daily for 12 weeks has been used (100023).

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD): Japanese apricot extract (Misatol ME, AdaBio Co. Ltd.) 6.5 grams twice daily for 12 weeks has been used (100023).
Standardization & Formulation
There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of Japanese apricot.

ANTICOAGULANT/ANTIPLATELET HERBS AND SUPPLEMENTS
Some constituents of Japanese apricot flower extract might have antiplatelet properties (13199). Theoretically, combining Japanese flower extract with other herbs and supplements that inhibit platelet aggregation might increase the risk of bleeding in some people due to Japanese Apricot's effects on platelet aggregation. Some other herbs with antiplatelet effects include angelica, clove, danshen, garlic, ginger, ginkgo, and many others.
HERBS AND SUPPLEMENTS WITH HYPOGLYCEMIC POTENTIAL
Japanese apricot fruit extract might reduce fasting blood glucose levels (100022). While this has not been shown in humans, theoretically, taking Japanese apricot along with other herbs and supplements with hypoglycemic potential might increase the risk of hypoglycemia. Some of these herbs and supplements include devil's claw, fenugreek, guar gum, Panax ginseng, Siberian ginseng, and others.
sections.Interactions with Conditions:
PERIOPERATIVE
Japanese apricot has antiplatelet and hypoglycemic effects (13199, 100022). Japanese apricot might cause excessive bleeding or affect blood glucose control if used perioperatively. Tell patients to discontinue Japanese apricot at least 2 weeks before elective surgical procedures.

sections.Overdose: There is insufficient reliable information available about the presentation or treatment of overdose with Japanese apricot.
sections.Pharmacokinetics:
Absorption
In rats, constituents of Japanese apricot fruit, including malic, protocatechuic, vanillic, quinic, citric, ferulic, syringic, cryptochlorogenic, neochlorogenic, and chlorogenic acids and amygdalin, are rapidly absorbed after oral administration, with times to peak plasma concentrations ranging from 0.15 to 0.92 hours (114032).
Distribution
In rats, the constituents of Japanese apricot fruit with the highest peak plasma concentrations and areas under the plasma concentration-time curves are malic and citric acids. Ferulic and vanillic acids undergo enterohepatic recirculation, giving double-peaked plasma concentration-time curves (114032).
Excretion
In rats, malic acid, citric acid, quinic acid, and amygdalin are excreted rapidly with half-lives of about 3, 2.75, 5, and 4 hours respectively. Constituents with longer half-lives include neochlorogenic acid (about 8 hours), syringic acid (about 11 hours), and protocatechuic, vanillic, ferulic, cryptochlorogenic, and chlorogenic acids (all about 9 hours) (114032).
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable parts of Japanese apricot are the seed, flower, branch, root, and fruit. The fruit contains phenols, organic acids (citric, malic, chlorogenic, protocatechuic, vanillic, caffeic, D-quinic, ferulic, syringic, cryptochlorogenic, neochlorogenic, maslinic, and corosolic acids), furfural, furfuryl alcohol, 3,4-dihydroxybenzaldehyde, benzyl beta-D-glucopyranoside, rutin, lignans including syringaresinol, sterols, terpenes, alkaloids, flavonoids, amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids, hydroxycinnamic acids, and triterpenoic acids (13198, 13201, 100021, 100023, 100027, 114030, 114032). The fruit is also a source of fiber (100016). The raw fruit is considered toxic because it contains the cyanogenic glycosides prunasin and amygdalin (13198). Processing by pickling in vinegar, liquor, or syrup to produce a fruit juice concentrate, eliminates the cyanogenic glycosides (13198). Japanese apricot flowers contain two polyacylated sucroses referred to as prunose I and prunose II, as well as 2-O-acetylrutin and 2-O-acetyl-3-O-methylrutin (13199). The seeds contain an aminopeptidase (13197).
Anti-bacterial effects
Japanese apricot has shown anti-bacterial effects against Helicobacter pylori in vitro and in animal models. The lignan syringaresinol, found in Japanese apricot, is thought to inhibit the migration of Helicobacter pylori. However, a small study in humans does not support a clinical effect for most patients (100023, 100026, 100029).
Anti-stress effects
Japanese apricot is traditionally used for menopause. In an animal menopause model, two constituents of Japanese apricot - benzyl beta-D-glucopyranoside and chlorogenic acid - inhibited bradykinin and prostaglandin E2 and stimulated the recovery of levels of epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. The chlorogenic acid constituent decreased levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) following induced stress (13201).
Anticancer effects
Japanese apricot is traditionally used for cancer. The extract has shown anticancer effects in various cell lines in vitro. Possible mechanisms include inducing apoptosis and cell cycle arrest by altering cellular signaling and/or by affecting cellular-mediated immunity (100023, 100025).
Cardiovascular effects
Several constituents of Japanese apricot have been shown to increase blood fluidity in vitro, including citric and malic acids, and furfuryl alcohol, as well as mumefural and 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furfural which are produced by heating Japanese apricot (13198). An ethanol extract of Japanese apricot bark has vasorelaxant and hypotensive effects in rats. The extract produces vascular smooth muscle relaxation via the nitric oxide / soluble guanylate cyclase / cyclic guanosine monophosphate and prostaglandin-I2 pathways and potassium channel activation (114030).
Exercise effects
Japanese apricot is traditionally used for fatigue. In an animal model of exercise-induced fatigue, it protects against the breakdown of muscle glycogen, possibly by inducing the use of fatty acids for fuel (100013). It also reduces lactate dehydrogenase activity and increases citrate synthase activity in rat skeletal muscle, inhibits accumulation of lactate and inorganic phosphate in serum, and reduces muscle injury by decreasing malondialdehyde and increasing glutathione peroxidase activity (114031). In humans with unexplained chronic muscle fatigue, taking Japanese apricot fermented juice orally, 70 mL daily for 8 weeks, reduces fatigue severity scale scores, but there is a strong and similar effect with placebo (114031).
Hepatoprotective effects
Japanese apricot has shown hepatoprotective effects in human and animal studies, resulting in reduced plasma levels of liver enzymes (100018, 100023, 100027). The hepatoprotective effects of Japanese apricot are possibly related to its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects (100027). Possible active constituents based on laboratory research are the triterpenoic acids (100023, 100027). In an animal model, various compounds were found in the blood after giving Japanese apricot, including saikosaponin BK1, N-2-[4-(3,3-Dimethylallyloxy) phenyl] ethylcinnamide, and ganoderiol 1. It is possible that these are constituents or metabolites of the fruit that play a role in the hepatoprotective effects of Japanese apricot (100018).
Hypoglycemic effects
In an animal diabetic model, Japanese apricot normalizes fasting glucose levels. The mechanism of action seems to be related to the regulation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR)-gamma (100022).
Hypolipemic effects
Japanese apricot is traditionally used to prevent cardiovascular disease. In human research, the extract reduces levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol and triglycerides in healthy individuals (100027). Japanese apricot extract has also been shown to inhibit an enzyme involved in the synthesis of cholesterol in vitro (100027).
Hypouricemic effects
Japanese apricot is traditionally used as part of gout medications. One potential mechanism is the inhibition of xanthine oxidase, resulting in the normalization of uric acid levels, as shown in an animal model (100015).

sections.Overview: Japanese mint is a perennial plant growing to about 18 inches in height that is native to North America and Asia. Japanese mint oil is the partially dementholated, distilled oil of the above ground parts of the plant (2, 11).
sections.Safety:
POSSIBLY SAFE when the oil is used orally and appropriately (2). ...when used topically and appropriately (2).
There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of Japanese mint for its other uses.
CHILDREN: LIKELY UNSAFE when the oil is used topically on the faces of infants and children, particularly in the nasal area. It has been reported to trigger glottal or bronchial spasm, asthma-like attacks, or even respiratory failure (2). There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of Japanese mint when used orally in children; avoid using.
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.

General
There is currently a limited amount of information on the adverse effects of Japanese mint. A thorough evaluation of safety outcomes has not been conducted.
Most Common Adverse Effects
Topically: Contact dermatitis.
Serious Adverse Effects (Rare)
Inhaled: Asthma, bronchial spasm, glottal spasm, respiratory failure.
Dermatologic
Topically, Japanese mint may cause contact dermatitis (11, 18).
less
Pulmonary/Respiratory
Topically, use of Japanese mint oil on the face in children can trigger glottal or bronchial spasm, asthma-like attacks, or respiratory failure (18). When inhaled, the vapor from Japanese mint oil can cause flushing, headache, or worsening bronchial asthma spasms (11, 18).

sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
Japanese mint oil contains menthol, menthone, isomenthone, neomenthol, methyl acetate, limonene, and 1,8-cineole (98006).
Anti-inflammatory effects
In an animal model of obesity, Japanese mint extract reduces pro-inflammatory cytokines, including monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 and resistin (115876).
Anti-obesity effects
In an animal model of obesity, Japanese mint extract reduces body weight and total white adipose tissue (115876).
Antimicrobial effects
Some evidence suggests that Japanese mint oil might have antimicrobial activity (11).
Antioxidant effects
Japanese mint oil has antioxidant effects in vitro (98006).
Gastrointestinal effects
Japanese mint oil is thought to have antiflatulent and cooling effects (2). It might also stimulate bile flow (2).

sections.Overview: Japanese persimmon is a tree that is widely distributed and cultivated throughout Asia (100447, 100448). The fruit is eaten as food, while the fruit and leaves have been used as medicine (13391, 13392, 100449).
sections.Safety:
POSSIBLY SAFE when the leaf extract or fruit fiber are used orally and appropriately. Japanese persimmon leaf extract 2 grams daily has been used with apparent safety in clinical research for up to 8 weeks (100449). Japanese persimmon fruit fiber 9-15 grams daily has also been used with apparent safety for up to 12 weeks (100446).
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
Orally, Japanese persimmon fruit may cause allergic reactions, including anaphylaxis, in sensitive people; however, this is rare (13391, 13392). Excessive consumption of Japanese persimmon fruit can cause bezoars (100444, 100456).
Gastrointestinal
Orally, excessive consumption of Japanese persimmon fruit can cause bezoars. In a case report, a 50-year-old male presented with a bezoar due to eating unpeeled Japanese persimmons with seeds for 10 years (100444). In another case report, a 73-year-old male with a history of partial stomach removal due to gastric cancer, presented with a bezoar due to consumption of 30-40 Japanese persimmon fruits in one season (100456).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Hyperlipidemia. One small clinical study in patients with elevated cholesterol levels shows that consuming cookie bars containing tannin-rich fiber from unripe Japanese persimmon fruit 3 or 5 grams three times daily before meals for 12 weeks lowers cholesterol levels when compared with placebo (100446).
Impaired glucose tolerance (prediabetes). Preliminary clinical research in patients with prediabetes shows that taking tablets of Japanese persimmon leaf extract 1 gram twice daily for 8 weeks modestly reduces two-hour postprandial glucose when compared with placebo (100449). It is unknown if Japanese persimmon reduces the risk of developing diabetes in people with prediabetes.
More evidence is needed to rate Japanese persimmon for these uses.
sections.Dosing & Administration:
Adult
Oral:
Hyperlipidemia: Cookie bars containing tannin-rich fiber from unripe Japanese persimmon fruit 3 or 5 grams three times daily before meals for 12 weeks has been used (100446).

Impaired glucose tolerance (prediabetes): Japanese persimmon leaf extract 1 gram twice daily for 8 weeks has been used (100449). Each 1-gram dose of extract reportedly contained 7.5 mg of quercetin and kaempferol.
Standardization & Formulation
There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of Japanese persimmon.

sections.Pharmacokinetics: There is insufficient reliable information available about the pharmacokinetics of Japanese persimmon.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable parts of Japanese persimmon are the leaf and fruit (13389). Biologically active constituents in Japanese persimmon include amino acids, carotenoids, flavonoids, tannins, catechins, procyanidins, polyphenols, vitamin A, and vitamin C (100450, 104761). The main polyphenol constituents of Japanese fruit extract include gallic acid, catechin, epicatechin, gallocatechin, gallocatechin gallate, and epicatechin gallate (104761). Fermenting Japanese persimmon fruit appears to increase the concentration of gallic acid and decrease the concentration of other polyphenol constituents (104760).
Anti-arthritic effects
Animal research shows that Japanese persimmon fruit extract reduces erythema, swelling, synovitis, and cartilage damage in rats with chemically-induced arthritis. This effect is thought to be a result of anti-inflammatory or anti-oxidant activity (104761).
Anti-inflammatory effects
Animal research shows that Japanese persimmon fruit extract reduces chemically-induced paw edema. This effect is thought to be a result of anti-inflammatory action (104761).
Anti-obesity effects
Fermented Japanese persimmon fruit extract may reduce fatty acid synthesis via activation of 5' adenosine monophosphate-activated protein kinase (AMPK) and downregulation of related genes in mice. Animal research shows that fermented Japanese persimmon fruit extract may reduce body weight, abdominal fat, liver fat, and cholesterol in mice that are fed high-fat diets (104760).
Anticancer effects
Preliminary research suggests that the peel of Japanese persimmon fruit might have antitumor effects (13390).
Antioxidant effects
Japanese persimmon extracts have antioxidant effects, which are thought to reduce the harm of gamma radiation, cardiovascular disease, and aging (100448, 100452, 100458, 104761). Naoxinqing (NXQ) tablet, a standardized herbal product that contains extract of Japanese persimmon leaves, is traditionally used for its purported antioxidant effects in patients with cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases. In vitro research shows that quercetin and kaempferol, ingredients isolated from Japanese persimmon leaf, have antioxidant activity (100448).

In vitro research also shows that proanthocyanidins extracted with acetone from Japanese persimmon peel reduce oxidative damage and expression of sirtuin 1 in a hydrogen peroxide-induced cellular senescence model. This suggests an anti-aging effect (100452).
Antipyretic effects
Japanese persimmon fruit appears to lower peripheral human body temperature (13389).
Antiviral effects
There is interest in using Japanese persimmon for its antiviral activity. In vitro research shows that Japanese persimmon extracts containing 22% tannins inhibit viral attachment to cells and inhibit viral infectivity. Tested viruses included influenza virus H3N2, H5N3, herpes simplex virus-1, poliovirus, adenovirus, rotavirus, and others (100455).
Bone effects
There is interest in using Japanese persimmon for slowing osteoporosis. Animal research shows that polysaccharides isolated from Japanese persimmon leaves reduce osteoclast activity and bone loss in mice models of postmenopausal osteoporosis (100447).
Cardiovascular effects
Both Japanese persimmon leaf and fruit juice reportedly have hypotensive effects (13389). Japanese persimmon leaf contains flavonoids such as astragalin. Astragalin seems to have hypotensive effects, possibly by inhibiting angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) activity (13388).

Extracts of Japanese persimmon leaf seem to have vasorelaxant activity, which might explain its use for hypertension. It might stimulate the release of the endothelial vasodilator, nitric oxide (13385). The leaf extract might also have free radical scavenging activity (13386). Other preliminary research suggests it might have immunological activity (13387).

Extracts of Japanese persimmon leaf also seem to have anticoagulant properties. Research in vitro shows that certain Japanese persimmon leaf extract protein fractions have anticoagulant activity. These fractions are thought to bind fibrinogen leading to thrombin inactivation (100454).
Dermatologic effects
Japanese persimmon leaf extract and astragalin appear to inhibit histamine release from mast cells (13388, 100450). Animal models of atopic dermatitis suggest that oral administration might relieve symptoms (13388). There is also interest in using Japanese persimmon leaves to prevent wrinkles and dark coloration. In vitro, ethanolic extracts of Japanese persimmon leaves inhibit xanthine oxidase inhibition, tyrosinase, collagenase, and elastase enzymes, which suggests that this extract has whitening and anti-wrinkle effects (100445).
Neurological effects
There is interest in using flavonoids from Japanese persimmon to slow progression of Alzheimer disease. Research from animal models shows that Japanese persimmon leaf extracts reduce learning and memory impairment, B-amyloid peptide production, and senile plaque activation (100453).
Ocular effects
There is interest in using Japanese persimmon to slow retinitis pigmentosa, age-related macular degeneration (AMD), and diabetic retinopathy because of its antioxidant effects and effects on angiogenesis. Animal models of AMD suggest that Japanese persimmon leaf extract increases retinal thickness and reduces oxidant effects of N-methyl-N-nitrosourea (100451). Animal research also suggests that Japanese persimmon ethanol extract improves angiogenesis and corneal neovascularization after alkali burns to the cornea (100457).

sections.Overview: Jasmine is a plant with strongly scented flowers and oil. It is used in perfumes, essential oils, aromatherapy, and food flavorings (11, 98684). Jasmine has been used for centuries to flavor tea, and also in traditional Chinese medicine (56970, 110678).
sections.Safety:
LIKELY SAFE when used orally in the amounts commonly found in foods. Jasmine has Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) status in the US (4912).
There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of jasmine in medicinal amounts.
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using in amounts greater than those found in food.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
Topically, jasmine may cause allergic contact dermatitis, delayed-type hypersensitivity, and type 1 hypersensitivity (56955, 57027, 57032, 98684).
Immunologic
Topically, jasmine essential oil and jasmine flower can cause allergic contact dermatitis (56955, 57027, 57032). Among patients who are sensitive to fragrance materials, jasmine may cause delayed-type hypersensitivity. The reported prevalence of this type of reaction ranges from 0.4% to 1.6% (89684). One case of type 1 hypersensitivity to jasmine has also been reported. The patient experienced chest tightness, wheezing, itchy skin, and macular erythematous eruption within minutes of exposure to jasmine. The eruption subsided within 20 minutes of moving away from the plant. An immunoblotting assay revealed IgE reactivity (98684).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Mental alertness. One preliminary clinical study shows that inhaling the aroma of jasmine essential oil while taking a visual vigilance test does not improve reaction time or accuracy when compared with placebo (57019). Another preliminary study in healthy male students shows that inhaling the aroma of jasmine essential oil for 30 minutes between concentration tests does not reduce mental fatigue when compared with placebo (56977).
More evidence is needed to rate jasmine for this use.
sections.Dosing & Administration:
Adult
Inhaled:
Research is limited; typical dosing is unavailable.
Standardization & Formulation
There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of jasmine.
sections.Interactions with Drugs: None known.
sections.Interactions with Supplements: None known.
sections.Overdose: There is insufficient reliable information available about the presentation or treatment of overdose with jasmine.
sections.Pharmacokinetics: There is insufficient reliable information available about the pharmacokinetics of jasmine.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable parts of jasmine are the flower and essential oil. Jasmine contains iridoids, such as ligstroside and oleuropein, secoiridoid glucosides, alkaloids, sterols, fatty acids, triterpenes, lignans, flavonoids, and terpenoids (56960, 56997, 110677). The flowers contain ligustin, oleuropein, and hydroxytyrosol (110678).
Anti-inflammatory effects
A methanol extract of the aerial parts of jasmine given in a dose of 400 mg/kg orally has anti-inflammatory activity in rat models of ulcerative colitis and rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The extract reduces ulcerative colitis disease activity similarly to prednisolone 2 mg/kg. It reduces proinflammatory myeloperoxidase, interferon-gamma, tumor necrosis factor alpha, interleukin (IL)-1, and IL-6 in colonic tissues. It also increases levels of the tight junction proteins claudin-5 and occludin in colonic epithelial cells (110677).

In the rat RA model, the extract reduces levels of rheumatoid factor, C-reactive protein, cathepsin-D, nitric oxide, and inducible nitric oxide synthase. It also reduces bone histopathological lesions, articular cartilage damage, and inflammation of synovial membrane and periarticular tissues, when compared with control animals (110677).
Anticancer effects
Jasmine is traditionally used in the prevention and treatment of cancer. In an animal model, jasmine flower extract prevents the formation of tumors, possibly due to antioxidant constituents (56978).
Antioxidant effects
The antioxidant effects of jasmine are due to phenolic and flavonoid compounds, including coumaroylquinic acid (110677).
Gastroprotective effects
In a mouse model of gastric ulcer induced by acid and ethanol, jasmine extracts alleviate ulceration by increasing prostaglandin E2 production and antioxidant enzyme activity, reducing lipid peroxidation, and reducing production of reactive oxygen species, apoptosis-related proteins, proinflammatory cytokines, and nitric oxide. Some extracts and the hydroxytyrosol ingredient reduce ulcer scores and histopathological changes, restore the thickness of the gastric mucous layer, and improve body weight, food and water intake, and flatulence (110678).
Relaxation effects
The smell of jasmine is thought to induce relaxation, slowing heart rate and improving mood (56975).
Spasmolytic effects
Jasmine is used for abdominal pain due to dysentery. It has spasmolytic effects in guinea pig ileum (56962).
Vasodilatory effects
In isolated thoracic aorta, jasmine extract has a vasodilatory effect. The mechanism of action seems to involve the calcium channels (57041).
Wound-healing effects
Jasmine is traditionally used topically for wound healing. Animal research shows that application of jasmine extract or a mucoadhesive containing jasmine leaves accelerates wound-healing, likely by improving epithelialization and collagen formation and reducing inflammatory cell infiltration (56994, 102542).

sections.Overview: Java tea is a perennial, herbaceous shrub. It is native to tropical and subtropical areas of Asia and Australia. It has been used to treat gout by the people of Yunnan Province, China for over 2000 years (18, 94851, 102764, 110427, 110428, 115754, 115757). Java tea is also traditionally used for bladder, gallbladder, kidney, and liver disorders.
sections.Safety:
POSSIBLY SAFE when used orally and appropriately, short-term. Java tea 100 mg daily has been safely used in a clinical trial for 8 weeks (94851).
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
Orally, Java tea seems to be well tolerated. No adverse effects have been reported. However, a thorough evaluation of safety outcomes has not been conducted.
sections.Effectiveness:
EXPAND ALL
|
COLLAPSE ALL
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Alzheimer disease. Although there has been interest in using oral Java tea for Alzheimer disease, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Java tea for this condition.
Chronic kidney disease (CKD). Although there has been interest in using oral Java tea for CKD, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Java tea for this condition.
Diabetes. Although there has been interest in using oral Java tea for diabetes, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Java tea for this condition.
Gout. Although there has been interest in using oral Java tea for gout, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Java tea for this condition.
Hypertension. Oral Java tea has only been evaluated in combination with other ingredients; its effect when used alone is unclear.
Preliminary clinical research in adults with uncontrolled hypertension shows that taking a specific combination product (OrthoSiphon, Rottapharm-Madaus SpA) containing Java tea leaf extract 100 mg, standardized to sinensetin 0.1%, berberine 500 mg, monakolin 3 mg, and policosanols 10 mg, daily for 8 weeks, reduces systolic and diastolic blood pressure by 5 mmHg and 2 mmHg, respectively, when compared to baseline. However, this supplement is less effective than hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily (94851). It is unclear if these effects are due to Java tea, other ingredients, or the combination.
less
Kidney stones (nephrolithiasis). Although there has been interest in using oral Java tea for kidney stones, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Java tea for this condition.
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Although there has been interest in using oral Java tea for RA, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of Java tea for this condition.
Urinary tract infections (UTIs). Oral Java tea has only been evaluated in combination with other ingredients; its effect when used alone is unclear.
Clinical research in females with UTIs who are not taking antibiotics shows that taking a specific combination supplement (Aqualibra, Medice Arzneimittel Ptter GmbH & Co. KG), containing extracts of Java tea 180 mg, spiny restharrow root 160 mg, and goldenrod 360 mg, 3 times daily for 7 days modestly improves symptom scores when compared with placebo. Urinary microbial counts decreased by 63% with the supplement, compared with 25% in those taking placebo. Antibiotics were needed in 15% and 49% of patients taking the supplement or placebo, respectively (102763). It is unclear if the effects are due to Java tea, other ingredients, or the combination.
less
More evidence is needed to rate Java tea for these uses.
sections.Dosing & Administration:
Adult
Oral:
Research is limited; typical dosing is unavailable.
Standardization & Formulation
In a specific combination supplement (OrthoSiphon, Rottapharm-Madaus SpA), an alcoholic leaf extract of Java tea was standardized to contain sinensetin 0.1% (94851).

Preliminary research in humans suggests that Java tea, in combination with other ingredients, has antihypertensive effects (94851).
