sections.Interactions with Supplements:
HERBS AND SUPPLEMENTS WITH HYPOGLYCEMIC POTENTIAL
Laboratory research suggests that constituents of Job's tears might have hypoglycemic effects (15363). Theoretically, concomitant use with other herbs and supplements that decrease blood glucose levels might increase the risk of hypoglycemia. Some of these products include bitter melon, cowhage, ginger, glucomannan, goat's rue, fenugreek, kudzu, willow bark, and others.
sections.Interactions with Conditions:
PERIOPERATIVE
Job's tears might affect blood glucose levels (15363). Theoretically, Job's tears might interfere with blood glucose control during and after surgical procedures. Tell patients to discontinue Job's tears at least 2 weeks before elective surgical procedures.
less
sections.Overdose: There is insufficient reliable information available about the presentation or treatment of overdose with Job's tears.
sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable parts of Job's tears are the root and the seeds. The root contains benzoxazinoid compounds (15361).The seed consists of 8.5% water, 17.6% protein, 52% starch, and 2.3% ash (15362). The seed also contains about 3% to 7% oil, which consists of about 1.6% phytosterols such as sitosterol, sitosterone, campersterol, and camperstanol (15362, 15364, 15372). The seed oils include palmitic, stearic, oleic, and linoleic fatty acids (15371). The seeds also contain 3 to 5 times the amount of B and E vitamins found in rice (111468).
Anti-obesity effects
In overweight or obese young adults, replacing refined grains with powdered Job's tears seeds, 60 grams daily at any meal for 6 weeks, decreases the percentage body fat, and total cholesterol and triglyceride levels when compared with baseline, but does not change body weight. Job's tears seed also lowers the inflammatory markers, tumor necrosis factor alpha and interleukins 6 and 10, and the marker of oxidative stress, malondialdehyde (111468).
Antidiabetic effects
Job's tears seeds have hypoglycemic activity in animal models, which is thought to be due to the coixan A, B, and C constituents 15363). In a mouse model of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), extracts of Job's tears seeds improve hyperglycemia, glucose tolerance, and insulin resistance (106512). Preliminary research in patients with type 2 diabetes shows that taking a porridge prepared from dried Job's tears seeds mixed with yogurt once daily for 12 weeks reduces plasma glycated albumin levels when compared with baseline (111465).
Antihypertensive effects
Research in hypertensive animals shows that adding 12% or 24% dehulled Job's tears seeds to the diet for 12 weeks limits further increases in blood pressure, when compared with a regular diet. In overweight or obese humans, eating 60 grams of dehulled Job's tears seeds daily for 6 weeks decreases systolic blood pressure, especially in those with high pressures at baseline. Possible mechanisms of an antihypertensive effect include reduction in levels of endothelin-1, a mediator of vasoconstriction and salt and water retention, and increased magnesium levels, stimulating prostacyclin and nitric oxide production to cause vasodilation (111220).
Antimicrobial effects
Powdered seed extract of Job's tears is thought to have activity against cutaneous warts. It's theorized that it stimulates cytotoxic activity against viral diseases (15362). Job's tears seed extract seems to have biostatic in vitro activity against the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, which causes toxoplasmosis. Components of Job's tears seed appear to activate macrophages against Toxoplasma gondii (15362). Some evidence shows that taking Job's tears seed in tablet form can increase cytotoxic T-lymphocyte and natural killer cell activity in animal models (15363).
Antineoplastic effects
Some extracts of Job's tears seed have anticancer activity. In animal and vitro studies, a methanolic extract of Job's tears seed inhibited lung cancer cell growth through cell cycle arrest and apoptosis; however, a water extract did not have this activity (15365). A methanolic extract of Job's tears seed also inhibited cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) expression, but not COX-1 expression, in lung cancer cells in animal and in vitro studies (15367). In an animal model of colon cancer, hulled Job's tears seed extract also inhibited COX-2 expression, but did not prevent the formation of colon tumors (15369). A lipid extracted from Job's tears seed also inhibited pancreatic cancer cell growth in vitro through cell cycle arrest and apoptosis (15371).
Antioxidant effects
Several constituents of Job's tears have antioxidant activity, including syringic acid, ferulic acid, syringaresinol, 4-ketopinoresinol, and the lignan mayuenolide (15368).
Gastrointestinal effects
Animal research shows that ingesting hulled Job's tears seed seems to alter the culture counts of enteric micro-organisms. Animals ingesting Job's tears appear to have higher cultures of lactic acid-producing bacteria and fewer enteric bacteria (15363). Human research in healthy adult males shows that consuming cooked Job's tears seeds, 106 grams daily for 7 days, increases intestinal Faecalibacterium abundance and alters the ratio of the different types of peripheral lymphocytes (natural killer, memory, helper and regulatory T-cells) (111467).
Hepatic effects
Research using fatty liver cell cultures or animal models of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), shows that dehulled Job's tears seeds, and extracts from them, reduce NAFLD progression by attenuating hepatic fat deposition, improving liver function, insulin resistance and steatosis, and reducing inflammation. Hepatic triglyceride and cholesterol levels, adipose leptin levels, and plasma fasting glucose levels are lowered. Downregulation of fatty acid synthesis and upregulation of fatty acid beta-oxidation occurs, along with decreased levels of C-reactive protein, tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interleukins 1-beta and 6. Increased plasma and adipose adiponectin levels contribute to the improved insulin sensitivity and reduced lipid accumulation in the liver (106512, 111469).
Immunologic activity
There is interest in Job's tears for allergies due to suspected anti-inflammatory activity. Job's tears root contains benzoxazinoid compounds, some of which might inhibit the release of histamine from mast cells in vitro (15361). Additionally, in animal models, Job's tears hulled seed extract decreases antigen-stimulated production of IgE antibodies. A methanolic extract appears to have greater activity than a water extract (15366).
Lipid effects
In a mouse model of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), extracts of Job's tears seeds attenuate increases in total and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, and triglycerides (15368, 106512). Preliminary research in patients with type 2 diabetes shows that taking a porridge prepared from dried Job's tears seeds mixed with yogurt once daily for 12 weeks reduces total and LDL cholesterol levels, and increases high density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels when compared with baseline (111465). Other research in healthy individuals shows that consuming 40-55 grams Job's tears seed powder as the sole carbohydrate source for breakfast, daily for 12 weeks, reduces total and HDL cholesterol, and triglycerides levels when compared with baseline (111466). Constituents of Job's tears that may contribute to lipid lowering effects include polyphenols, phytosterols, and fiber, which includes 32% slowly digestible or resistant starch (111466).
Metabolic effects
There is interest in Job's tears for weight loss. In animal models of obesity, a Job's tears seed extract reduces food intake, body weight, cholesterol levels, adipose tissue mass, and leptin in animals fed a high fat diet (15370). Job's tears oil also appears to reduce LDL cholesterol, insulin, and leptin in animal models (15372).

sections.Overview: Jojoba (Simmondsia chinensis) is a shrub native to deserts in Arizona, California and Mexico (57172, 57185) and is also found in some arid African countries (57177). The oil (or liquid wax) in jojoba seeds contains extremely long (C36-C46) straight chain fatty acids in the form of wax esters, as opposed to triglycerides (57171). It is this structure that allows it to be easily refined for use in cosmetics and as a carrier oil for fragrances. Jojoba meal, remaining after oil extraction, is rich in protein (57172). In Japan, jojoba oil (wax) is used as a food additive (57179). The use of jojoba oil in various applications is limited by its high price (57180). Jojoba meal can be used as an animal feedstuff (57188).
sections.Safety:
LIKELY SAFE when used topically (6).
LIKELY UNSAFE when used orally because it contains 14% erucic acid, which can cause myocardial fibrosis (6); avoid using.
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: LIKELY SAFE when used topically for hygienic uses (6).
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: LIKELY UNSAFE when used orally (6).
sections.Adverse Effects:
EXPAND ALL
|
COLLAPSE ALL
General
Side effects of jojoba are mainly limited to contact dermatitis and gastrointestinal concerns in animals fed large amounts of jojoba meal.
Dermatologic
Contact dermatitis to jojoba oil has been described in case reports (57197, 57186).
less
Endocrine
Levels of plasma growth hormone and thyroxine increased and levels of plasma insulin-like growth factor-I and triiodothyronine decreased in animals fed diets of 4% jojoba meal (57195).
less
Gastrointestinal
In animals fed jojoba oil for four weeks (2.2-9% of diet), necropsy and histopathological evaluation revealed an apparent distension of the small intestine and marked intestinal changes characterized by massive vacuolization and lipid deposition in the enterocytes, accompanied by distension of the villi and an increased cell turnover of small intestinal cells (57189).
less
Genitourinary
In broiler breeding females fed jojoba meal, the size of the eggs laid were smaller and the overall production rate was lower than birds not fed jojoba (57164). Ovary and oviduct weights were also reduced. In female rats fed defatted jojoba meal or pure simmondsin, the number of corpora lutea on gestation day 16 as reduced, and this was thought to be due to decreased food intake in this group (57199). Fetal and placental weights were also reduced in these groups.
less
Hematologic
In animals fed jojoba oil for four weeks (2.2-9% of diet), there was a dose related increase in white blood cell count (57189).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Acne. One low quality clinical study shows that applying a clay facial mask containing jojoba oil, 15 minutes 2-3 times weekly for 6 weeks, might reduce the number of whiteheads, blackheads, papules, and pustules in patients with acne (95436). The results of this study are questionable due to the lack of a control group.
Alzheimer disease. One small clinical trial shows that massaging the hand with jojoba oil does not improve emotions, aggression, or cognitive function in patients with Alzheimer disease (57178).
Mosquito repellent. One small clinical study shows that topical application of a repellant containing jojoba oil, coconut oil, rapeseed oil, and vitamin E provides complete protection against mosquito bites for at least 3 hours. Some protection remains for up to 6 hours, but to a lesser degree than is seen with a repellant containing deet 15% (13081). The effect of jojoba alone as a mosquito repellant is unclear.
More evidence is needed to rate jojoba for these uses.
sections.Dosing & Administration:
Adult
Acne: A clay facial mask containing jojoba oil, applied topically for 15 minutes 2-3 times weekly for 6 weeks, has been used (95436).
Standardization & Formulation
There is insufficient reliable information available about the standardization of jojoba.
sections.Interactions with Drugs: None known.
sections.Interactions with Supplements: None known.
sections.Overdose: Booth described the isolation of a 'toxic factor' from jojoba meal in 1974 (57190) and the removal of toxic compounds was later developed (57187). Treatment of jojoba meal and seed without seed coat with hexane and a 7:3 isopropanol-water mixture has been used to remove 86% of total phenolic compounds and 100% of simmondsins originally present; the resulting product caused no deaths in experimental animals. Removal of toxic compounds does allow jojoba meal to be an alternative feedstuff for animals in regions were jojoba is produced (57188). Lactobacilli have also been used to detoxify jojoba meal (57192, 57194).
sections.Pharmacokinetics:
In an animal model, absorption of jojoba 14C-labelled liquid wax was investigated (57191). Intragastric administration resulted in the majority of the wax being excreted. A small amount was absorbed, and distributed in internal organs, epididymal fat, and body lipids.


The final step in liquid wax biosynthesis in the jojoba seed is catalyzed by fatty-acyl-coenzyme A (CoA): fatty alcohol acyltransferase (57171). Beta-Ketoacyl-coenzyme A (CoA) synthase activity, involved in the formation of very long chain fatty acids, such as found in jojoba waxes, is present in developing jojoba embryos (57196).


The appetite suppressing effects of jojoba seed meal is reduced when the meal is treated with 1N NaOH at 20oC resulting in the destruction of simmondsin (57175). End products include d-glucose and 2-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenylacetonitrile and intermediates included isosimmondsin and a simmondsin lactone derivative.


Boiling of jojoba meal has been suggested to inactivate protease inhibitors and the denaturation of proteins, resulting in increased digestibility (57172).
sections.Mechanism of Action:
Anti-inflammatory effects
Habashy examined the anti-inflammatory effects of jojoba liquid wax in several animal and in vitro models (57177). Jojoba liquid wax reduced carrageenin-induced rat paw edema and prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) levels in inflammatory exudates. In a chick embryo chroioallantoic membrane model, jojoba liquid wax caused a reduction in granulation tissue formation. In rats, croton oil induced ear edema was reduced. In this model, there was also a reduction in neutrophil infiltration (decreased myeloperoxidase activity) and histopathological changes. Jojoba liquid wax reduced nitric oxide levels and tumor necrosis factor-alpha release in a lipopolysaccharide-induced inflammation rat air pouch model.


Anti-insect effects
Topical application of the prepupae of Rhynchophorus ferrugineous with one of three dose-levels (0.1, 0.005 or 0.001mcg per insect) of jojoba oil decreased daily O2 consumption and CO2 release of early and late pupae (57173). This suggests jojoba oil may have use a general insecticide.


Appetite suppressant effects
The appetite suppressing effects of jojoba seed meal is reduced when the meal is treated with 1N NaOH at 20oC, resulting in the destruction of simmondsin (57175).


Cholesterol reducing effects
The effects of jojoba oil on blood cholesterol levels have been investigated in an animal model (57193).


Constituents
In jojoba meal, the major proteins are albumins (79%) and globulins (21%) (57172). Residual meal analysis resulted in crude protein 25.24%; ether extract 14.73%; crude fiber 10.07%; ash 4.72, nitrogen-free extract 45.25, and trypsin inhibitor factors 11,197TIU/g (57188). A trypsin-inhibitory substance, able to inhibit the enzymic activity of trypsin, chymotrypsin, and pepsin, but not the protease from Aspergillus saotoi, has been identified in commercially processed jojoba seed meal and the albumin fraction of seed proteins (57183). It is unclear whether consumption of jojoba seed meal by humans would inhibit trypsin activity in the intestine.

In jojoba meal, 1-oleoyl-3-lysophosphatidylcholine and 1,2-dioleoyl-3-phosphatidylcholine (57176), the pinnitol alpha-D-galactosides 5-O-(alpha-D-galactopyranosyl)-3-O-methyl-D-chiro-inositol or 5-alpha-D-galactopyranosyl-D-pinitol and 2-O-(alpha-D-galactopyranosyl)-3-O-methyl-D-chiro-inositol or 2-alpha-D-galactopyranosyl-D-pinitol (57170, 57200), and simmondsin [2-(cyanomethylene)-3 hydroxy 4,5 dimethoxy cyclohexyl beta-D-glucoside] and simmondsin ferulates (57167, 57168) were identified. Simmondsin, 4-demethylsimmondsin, 5-demethylsimmondsin and 4,5-didemethylsimmondsin were isolated from jojoba seed meal (57174).


With fermentation, five strains of simmondsin-degrading, lactic-acid-producing bacteria were isolated from jojoba meal (57169).


Seed analysis resulted in crude protein 14.03%; ether extract 48.89%; crude fiber 10.03%; ash 1.59, nitrogen-free extract 25.46, and trypsin inhibitor factors 13.747TIU/g (57188).


The jojoba plant synthesizes liquid wax (57171). Wax levels may represent up to 70% (by weight) of the oil present in jojoba seeds (57166, 57181, 57165). The main constituents in jojoba wax are the wax esters, eicosenyl octadecenoate (C20:1-C18:1), eicosenyl eicosenoate (C20:1-C20:1), docosenyl eicosenoate (C22:1-C20:1), eicosenyl docosenoate (C20:1-C22:1) and tetracosenyl eiosenoate (C24:1-C20:1) (57179). A wax ester hydrolase is active in developing jojoba cotyledons (57182).


Jojoba seed is a source of xyloglucan oligosaccharides, which may be a convenient source of individual oligosaccharides (57198).


Aminopeptidase activity has been determined in germinated jojoba cotyledon extracts (57184). This protein is thought to be involved in the degradation of globulin reserve proteins during cotyledon senescence.

sections.Overview: Juniper is an evergreen tree found in India, southwest Asia, Europe, and North America (12230, 94060). The berries, aerial parts, and bark are all used for various medicinal purposes (94060). There are many varieties of juniper, but Juniperus communis is the most common in North America (12230).
sections.Safety:
LIKELY SAFE when used orally in amounts commonly found in foods. Juniper, juniper berry, and juniper extract have Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) status in the US (4912).
POSSIBLY SAFE when used topically on limited areas of skin (12230). ...when the oil is used by inhalation and appropriately as aromatherapy (7107).
LIKELY UNSAFE when used orally in excessive amounts or long-term. Use of daily doses greater than 10 grams of juniper berries (about 60 berries) or 100 mg of juniper essential oil, or prolonged oral use longer than 4 weeks, have been reported to increase the risk of severe adverse effects such as convulsions or kidney damage (8, 19, 103759).
There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of juniper when used orally in doses of less than 10 grams of berries or 100 mg of oil daily, short-term. Juniper oil and berry have a long history of traditional use (12, 103759).
PREGNANCY: UNSAFE when used orally. Juniper can increase uterine tone, interfere with fertility and implantation, and cause abortion (4, 19).
LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
EXPAND ALL
|
COLLAPSE ALL
General
Orally and topically, juniper seems to be generally well tolerated when used short-term in low doses. However, a thorough evaluation of safety outcomes has not been conducted.
Most Common Adverse Effects
Topically: Allergies, skin irritation.
Dermatologic
Topically, juniper can cause skin irritation. Signs of topical poisoning include burning, erythema, inflammation with blisters, and edema (4). Repeated exposure to the juniper pollen can cause occupational allergies that affect the skin (6). In a case report, a 62-year-old woman developed burn-like blistering lesions after carrying juniper in close contact to her skin. Concurrent sun exposure was thought to worsen the skin irritation caused by juniper (103756).
less
Genitourinary
Orally, large amounts of the juniper berry can cause purplish urine (4).
less
Pulmonary/Respiratory
Repeated exposure to the juniper pollen can cause occupational allergies that affect the respiratory tract (6).
less
sections.Effectiveness:
INSUFFICIENT RELIABLE EVIDENCE TO RATE
Bronchitis. Although there has been interest in using inhaled juniper essential oil for bronchitis, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Cancer. Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for cancer, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Diabetes. Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for diabetes, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Dyspepsia. Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for dyspepsia, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Flatulence. Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for flatulence, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for GERD, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Intestinal parasite infection. Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for intestinal parasite infection, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Kidney stones (nephrolithiasis). Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for nephrolithiasis, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Although there has been interest in using topical juniper for RA, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Urinary tract infections (UTIs). Although there has been interest in using oral juniper for UTIs, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
Wound healing. Although there has been interest in using topical juniper for wound healing, there is insufficient reliable information about the clinical effects of juniper for this purpose.
More evidence is needed to rate juniper for these uses.

sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
Juniper berries and leaves contain flavonoids including apigenin, rutin, and luteolin (12230, 57203, 57215, 94060). Juniper berry oil is mostly composed of monoterpenes including alpha-pinene (51.4%), myrcene (8.3%), sabinene (5.8%), limonene (5.1%), and beta-pinene (5.0%) (94060). The seeds and fruit also contain glycolic acid, formic acid, malic acid, acetic acid, ascorbic acid, and camphor (94060). Various extracts of juniper made from dried stems showed differing amounts of constituents including flavonoids, volatile oil, and coumarins (94060). Juniper extracts also contain flavonoids, tannins, alkaloids, diterpenes, sesquiterpenes, and neolignan glycosides (12230, 57208, 94060).
Abortifacient effects
Abortions have been induced in cattle fed juniper (57211). Isocrupressic acid has been identified as an active abortifacient compound in juniper.
Analgesic effects
Juniper seems to have some antinociceptive activity and likely acts both peripherally and centrally. In animal research, a methanolic extract of juniper exhibited a dose dependent effect on the writhing response (94060). Additionally, in mice, intravenous administration of a lyophilized aqueous extract of juniper produced an analgesic response of 178% as measured by thermal stimuli (57219).
Anti-inflammatory effects
Juniper fruit has demonstrated inhibition of prostaglandin and platelet activating factor exocytosis in vitro (94060). Oral administration of an ethanolic extract of juniper reduced carrageenan-induced rat paw edema by 60% compared to 45% for indomethacin (13466).
Antibacterial effects
Juniper berry has demonstrated antibacterial effects in vitro (4, 10939, 103755). Juniper berries showed activity against Escerichia coli, Staphylococcus aureus, and Hafnia alvei. A hexane extract of juniper leaf appears to have more antibacterial activity compared to ethanol, methanol, and chloroform extracts (94060). Volatile oils of Juniperus communis have higher activity against S. aureus when compared with other juniper species (103755).
Antidiabetic effects
In animals, juniper berry seems to reduce blood glucose levels and decrease polydipsia. It appears to work primarily by increasing peripheral glucose uptake (10580, 14907, 94060).
Antifungal effects
Juniper berry oil has demonstrated antifungal effects in vitro (4, 10939).Oil from the aerial parts of juniper has shown some activity against Rhizoctonia solani and Rhizopus stolonifer. This activity is thought to be due to the monoterpenes found in juniper (94060).
Antimalarial effects
Essential oil from juniper has shown some activity against Plasmodium falciparum in vitro (94060).
Antioxidant effects
In vitro research shows that juniper can block the oxidation process and increase the activity of antioxidant enzymes (94060).
Cardiac effects
Intravenous administration of a lyophilized aqueous extract of juniper, 25 mg/kg body weight, to normotensive rats produced an initial transient rise in arterial pressure followed by a reduction of 27% (57219). The mechanism of these effects is unclear.
Diuretic effects
The diuretic action of juniper has been attributed to terpinen-4-ol (57207). However, some animal research suggests that the diuretic effect is partly due to the essential oil and partly to hydrophilic constituents (57218). The magnitude of juniper's diuretic effects is unclear, as some animal research shows that aqueous juniper extract is no more effective than water at increasing urine volume while other animal research shows significant effects only at higher concentrations (57218, 57219).
Hepatoprotective effects
Juniper has demonstrated hepatoprotective effects in animal research. Compared with rats receiving placebo, rats receiving juniper and then exposed to CCl4 had less pronounced increases in serum SGPT, SGOT, ALP, and bilirubin. Ethanol and aqueous extracts of juniper may be more effective (94060). The mechanism of these effects is unclear.
Lipid effects
Animal research shows that juniper methanolic extract and oil can increase high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol and decrease low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, respectively, in diabetic rats (94060). The mechanism of these effects is unclear.
Neurologic effects
A methanolic extract of juniper has been shown to reduce reserpine induced catalepsy compared with reserpine alone in rats. (94060). Juniper has also shown some neuroprotective activity in a chlorpromazine induced Parkinson's model in rats (94060). The mechanism of these effects is unclear.

sections.Overview: Justicia pectoralis is a flowering herb that is native to tropical regions of the Americas, including South and Central America, and some Caribbean islands including Trinidad and Tobago (29151, 29155, 103381).
sections.Safety:
There is insufficient reliable information available about the safety of Justicia pectoralis.
PREGNANCY AND LACTATION: Insufficient reliable information available; avoid using.
sections.Adverse Effects:
General
No adverse effects have been reported. However, a thorough evaluation of safety outcomes has not been conducted.
sections.Effectiveness: There is insufficient reliable information available about the effectiveness of Justicia pectoralis.

sections.Mechanism of Action:
General
The applicable part of Justicia pectoralis is the leaf (103381). Justicia pectoralis contains coumarin, 7-hydroxycoumarin (umbelliferone), dihydrocoumarin, 3-(2-hydroxyphenyl)propionic acid, and flavonoids including apigenin and ellagic acid (29156, 103381). Hallucinogenic alkaloids have not been identified in Justicia pectoralis (29148).
Anti-asthmatic effects
Justicia pectoralis is traditionally used for asthma, bronchitis, and other lung conditions. In isolated guinea-pig trachea, Justicia pectoralis extract had bronchodilator effects (29153).
Anti-inflammatory effects
Justicia pectoralis is traditionally used as an anti-inflammatory agent. In vitro, Justicia pectoralis extract inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX)-2 activity and inhibits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (29150, 103381). However, in animal research, although the extract had antinociceptive effects, it did not have anti-inflammatory effects (29153).
Antibacterial effects
Justicia pectoralis is traditionally used as an antibacterial agent. In vitro, it has shown antibacterial effects against some, but not all, species tested (29151, 103381).
Hormonal effects
Justicia pectoralis is traditionally used for menopausal symptoms and premenstrual syndrome (PMS). In vitro, Justicia pectoralis extract binds to the progesterone receptor and the alpha- and beta-estrogenic receptors, inducing the expression of estrogen responsive genes (29150).
